The fact that she cold make the transition to Aerial Skiing and be Olympic eligible in just seven months is remarkable, but it demonstrates that this sport is more akin to Gymnastics than to Skiing, which is difficult and dangerous in its own right. She has become the victim of Brazil's desire to excel in sports that it has no experience in and her coach's poor judgement in taking her to an expert run, when she was barely more than a novice skier. It is sad, but she has a changed life and now will have tackle different challenges which are more daunting than any she has faced before. I hope she can stay positive and succeed.

That's ridiculous- the republicans have everything to do with it. You need funding to put in place the systems that can override operator error. There is a law in place to require it. The republicans refuse to fund it. Period. End of story.

"With her days of longing to be an Olympic athlete behind her, Laís Souza sets her sights now on much smaller accomplishments."

I don't think there is anything small about the accomplishments Laís is making now. We take so much in life for granted that we forget how difficult and large many of our own accomplishments are. I think her strength, determination, and desire to keep moving forward in the face of such adversary is a stunning accomplishment and larger than the narrow definition of successes as participating in a singular competition.

I do so hope that God will be very close to her and will be setting tasks before her, whatever they may be. After all, she is in my mind, buried alive.

I can't get this story out of my mind. It haunts me.

Now i read about kids taking the same risks with other dare devil sports. Are we that bored, that mindless, that idiotic and insecure that we feel we have to do this?
The most poignant moment in this heart-rending piece is when the young woman says that she prefers to look upon the task that God has now set before her. Bravo to her for her courage and equanimity.

But she didn't get hurt doing aerials. She got hurt doing moguls. The truth is no one knows why she had this accident. Readers aren't going to just "believe" the coach played no role simply because you tell us he's a great guy.

It's not fair for people to automatically blame the coach either. But it seems fishy that Brazil would try to field a ski team. If a country has to hire a foreign coach who relies on Google Translate to talk to athletes, and has to train those athletes in foreign countries, and not only that but it has to poach the athletes from other sports - especially one like gymnastics which is known for aging its athletes out a very young age - then doesn't it kind of defeat the purpose of being an Olympic sport? Why not just recruit American gymnasts to represent Brazil if the only goal here is for Brazil to cart home some winter medals??

Plus, any sport based entirely on retraining former gymnasts sounds like a dubious proposition. The reason Olympic sports are interesting to watch is that you know the athletes have spent their lives training for THAT event. If gymnasts want longer careers, then maybe something about gymnastics needs to change.

If nothing else, my respect for the Olympics went down a notch, if that's possible in this day and age.

My son took gymnastics for years and was also swimming for the upper body strength needed. At puberty he sprang up to 6 feet tall and had to drop gymnastics. His center of gravity and added bulk was too high to do most of the feats so he expanded his time in swimming so that he was on three teams at once.
The girls have a similar issue. Note that all these gymnasts a very small.
All these young kids want to be in sports. It could be the sense of achievement when you master a move or just the competition that drives them. When they age or grow out of one they'll attempt another. I would hope that she realized the risks involved and wasn't just led by adults pushing her but I think we have to recognize the drive they have.

It is very nice of you Jaime to defend your ex coach but the 4 points you made do not really defend him fairly. A fair defense would be more objective and to accept his mistake. If you are a skier like me you know that a steep bumpy "5 or 6 yard across" run into a forest is extremely difficult and dangerous! Unless you are an experience mogul skier 5 or 6 yard is barely enough to make a turn! So what about a beginner? It was totally unconscious of him. He messed up. There's no way to defend this action.
*1-Being the best coach in the world is not an excuse.
*2-Skiing on plastic is difficult but doesn't teach you how to ski in steep moguls!
*3-"Taking former gymnasts and turning them into aerialist is what almost every country does for aerials" -> that's totally wrong!!!!
*4-Portuguese is a very easy language and if you still rely on google translate after 6 months training the Brazilian team that's another big problem ito the equation here! Even soccer coach learn new language on the go many time sin their life and they have to talk about tactics and need way more vocabulary. I did aerials so i know a bit about the need. A good or serious coach would never rely on google translate , particularly at this level and for such a dangerous sport. This is insane!

I wish I could reply 2 everyone's comments on here. But I don't have that kind of time & I'm only allowed 1500 words to argue all "assumptions".
*1st of all that "coach" is 1 of the best aerials coaches in the world. I know this b/c he was my aerials coach for almost 3yrs. In aerials you have to trust yr life to yr coach because they are yr eyes while u are in the air. U trust them on speed, wind, & every imaginable weather condition to be cleared to ski into a jump. Aerials coaches know their athletes inside and out.
*2nd, skiing down an aerials outrun & skiing on the plastic on the water ramps is 5x harder than skiing down DBL Black Jack with moguls in the fog. I've seen skiers (myself included) who have skied a lifetime & become seriously injured skiing down an aerials out run or trying to ski into an aerials jump. If Snow thought she could ski that run, then absolutely she could.
*3rd taking former gymnasts and turning them into aerialist is what almost every country does for aerials. US included.
*4th Learning a new language is hard in any condition. Aerials/ skiing terms & movement explanations in another language is actually really hard. I know a lot of intl coaches who have spent 15+ yrs who still struggle with trying to communicate coaching terms in a diff language.
*Lastly. This accident & that is exactly what it is, a very tragic accident. something that Snow will take to his core. He is extremely sensitive & cares very deeply about his athletes.

Nothing yellow or sensational about Assad's use of chemical weapons in his war against his own people. It is  all true. Over 200,000 are dead and millions have emigrated because of Bachir Assad's systematic murder of his fellow Syrians,."Yellow journalism" was a term which came into use during William Randolph Hearst's day to mobilize public opinion for a war against Spain in the late 19th century. Casualties on both sides  were minimal, although  it did usher in a period of American imperialism.But the comparison with the genocide in Syria, which we have condoned by drawing a red line but not enforcing it is a trifle ludicrous.Turning points are not always recognized for what they are at the time, but the adminstration's last minute decision not to order air strikes against Assad's air force in 2012, in an apparent attempt to ingratiate ourselves to Iran, for whom Syria is a client state,caused many in the ME to lose respect for us, and to regard our chief of state as whimsical, capricious.Not an enviable image for the leader of the free world to have.

Infrastructure? 106 mph has nothing to do with infrastructure

The Northeast Corridor tracks where this accident occurred are owned, maintained and dispatched by Amtrak. The rail passenger company also owns the 104-mile Keystone Corridor between Philadelphia and Harrisburg, Pennsylvania; the 60-mile Springfield Line from New Haven, Connecticut, to Springfield, Massachusetts; and a 96-mile segment in Michigan and Indiana. All of its other routes are owned, maintained and dispatched by the nation's freight railroads. Amtrak is the only railroad in North America to maintain right of way for service at speeds in excess of 100 mph.

To be honest, a subsidy for Amtrak is a subsidy for the upper middle class. I travel by Amtrak because I am upper middle class, but people who are poor or middle class tend to travel by Boltbus or Megabus because their cost for a trip from New York to Boston is one third (or less) than the cost of Amtrak.

Even in Europe, going from Amsterdam to Bristol, I very much wanted to go by train but found the train to take longer and be more expensive. So I gave in and went by plane.

Just now I know two people who are going from New York to New Orleans by train. The cost is $700 per person. The return airfare is $224 if you book in advance.

I like trains myself, but the idea that they are "mass transportation" is nothing other than sentimentality coming from people who wish they were Europeans. But in reality even Europeans travel less by train than they do by car or plane.

All four mainline tracks where this accident occurred are laid with highly-maintained, continuous-welded rail attached to concrete ties. Even on perfect roadbed, the laws of physics dictate the top speed a train can travel around a curve without centrifugal force causing it to fall over.

Our government is too poor to fund what you have in mind, and our private sector is too cautious to do so.

You need a strong AND rich government (think East Asian) to build a high speed rail network.
No, China has modern high speed rail. They take curves at 200+ MPH no problem. Japan's Shinkansen bullet trains only slow down a tiny bit around large curves, but still never goes slower than 180MPH.
And flimsy cover at that.

"Mr. Sumwalt said positive train control could have prevented the crash."

Faulty Automatic Train Controls resulted in 9 deaths and approximately 80 injuries in the June 2009 Washington, D.C. Metro Red Line Accident.

In this day and age, when modern trains in first world countries can travel at up to 280 kpm, lack of funding is indeed responsible for having an antiquated 50-mph curve on a track without any kind of speed regulation mechanism on the train.  It's pretty clear that most congresspersons and senators have little interest in the lives and safety of those of us who travel by train.
